Award.AwardTitle: Transforming STEM Education at Small Rural Colleges: Incorporation of Remote Access NMR to Create an Authentic Laboratory Environment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is introducing an NMR spectrometer to a remote access instrumentation network serving five small, rural colleges in the northern plains. Remote access collaboration experiments and mini-projects are being developed for student teams who will not physically meet each other. Students enrolled in introductory, general and organic chemistry, regardless of their location, directly operate the NMR to analyze their own samples. An online teaching and learning community for the instructors involved in the project is being established to promote additional understanding of strategies to enhance student learning using remote access instrumentation networks. The intellectual merit includes development of new curricular materials and pedagogies to transform how small, remote colleges approach educating students, by providing authentic hands-on learning experiences, instead of relying on simulations and published materials. The broader impacts of the proposal include improved infrastructure for teaching and research at all five campuses through acquisition of the NMR. Multi-layered evaluation is being used to measure the impact on students' (a) content knowledge, laboratory skills and engagement, (b) ability to transfer and integrate knowledge between the laboratory and lecture courses, and (c) professional skills, such as critical thinking, communication, collaboration and professional behaviors. Dissemination of the project's benefits and challenges provides a model for other small colleges to provide hands-on remote access to modern instrumentation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The American Chemical Society (ACS) Guidelines for Two-Year College Programs specify that the laboratories should have access to modern instrumentation, such as infrared spectroscopy (IR), nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR) and mass spectroscopy (MS), to analyze chemical compounds. The expense of acquiring and maintaining instrumentation is not feasible for small colleges that possess limited budgets. A common remedy is to collaborate with larger, nearby institutions. For colleges located in rural areas, traveling to an instrumentation facility at a larger institution is impractical because of the considerable distances between institutions.

To address the challenge encountered by small, rural colleges, the North Dakota State College of Science (NDSCS), a two-year college located in Southeast North Dakota, established a remote access instrumentation center. The instrumentation center consists of industry-standard NMR spectroscopy, IR spectroscopy, gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS), gas chromatography (GC) and high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). All instruments are completely accessible over the Internet; performing experiments, processing data and printing results can be achieved from any location with Internet access. Our emphasis is to serve small, rural two-year and four-year colleges that possess limited budgets. We can provide a virtually exclusive access to the instrumentation facility because there are no large research groups or large undergraduate classes monopolizing the instruments.

The NSF-TUES grant funding allowed NDSCS to purchase a 90 MHz NMR and to create the remote access instrumentation center which is located in Wahpeton, ND. Remote access operation of each instrument was identical to being physically at the instrument. Each instrument was successfully operated remotely during the funding period; parameter set up, data acquisition, processing and printing were performed from the remote sites. Operation manuals were created for each instrument which included the basic operation of the instrument: sample preparation, method development, instrument operation, and data analysis. An experiment database and NMR compound library were established to assist faculty with incorporating instrumentation into their classes and to provide potential collaborations. The goals for the remote operators are to have the same operational experience and for the remote access students to experience similar learning gains as the on-site instrument operators; the assessment is ongoing.

The NSF funding also allowed for the development of experiments and mini research-based projects that utilized the instrumentation center. A total of 16 new experiments and 2 new projects were developed and implemented into the introductory chemistry, general chemistry and organic chemistry curricula. Each experiment used a guided-inquiry approach where students designed significant portions of the experiment and where the final results were not known to students in advance. General chemistry and organic chemistry students participated in the research-based projects. The students developed the entire research plan, executed the plan and revised the plan as necessary while the instructor acted as a consultant.

The remote access instrumentation center has strengthened the STEM infrastructure at NDSCS and the remote access colleges. The project impacted 260 first-year and second-year students during the funding period, which included every NDSCS general chemistry and organic chemistry student enrolled during the funding period. Each student operated at least one instrument either remotely or on-site. Students experienced an authentic laboratory environment and acquired transferable laboratory and professional skills. Student surveys indicated that they have confidence in their abilities to learn new laboratory skills and the belief that instrumentation added to the laboratory experience. 

Opportunities exist to establish the remote instrumentation center as an effective educational resource for small colleges with limited budgets. We will continue to support our original partners, but will also actively pursue new partnerships. We are committed to the long-term success of the remote access instrumentation program, to the assessment of the impact to student learning and engagement, and to the dissemination our results in peer-reviewed publications.
